Question 72:

Explain how to create a line plot in Matplotlib with proper labels and title.
(Source: )

‚úÖ Introduction

A line plot is used to show trends over time.

It connects data points with lines.

In business analytics, line plots help in:

‚úî Tracking sales growth
‚úî Monitoring stock prices
‚úî Observing revenue trends
‚úî Measuring performance over months

üîπ Basic Syntax

python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.plot(x_values, y_values)
plt.show()

üîπ Example: Monthly Sales Trend

python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

months = ["Jan", "Feb", "Mar", "Apr"]
sales = [10000, 15000, 12000, 18000]

plt.plot(months, sales)

plt.xlabel("Month")
plt.ylabel("Sales")
plt.title("Monthly Sales Trend")

plt.show()

üîπ Explanation of Each Part

1Ô∏è‚É£ plt.plot()

Creates the line graph.

2Ô∏è‚É£ plt.xlabel()

Labels the X-axis.

3Ô∏è‚É£ plt.ylabel()

Labels the Y-axis.

4Ô∏è‚É£ plt.title()

Adds a title to the graph.

5Ô∏è‚É£ plt.show()

Displays the plot.

üîπ Why Labels and Title Are Important

Without labels:

‚ùå Graph becomes confusing
‚ùå Hard to understand data

With labels:

‚úî Clear meaning
‚úî Professional presentation
‚úî Better interpretation

üîπ Business Importance

Suppose company tracks sales for 12 months.

Line plot helps management:

‚úî Identify growth pattern
‚úî Detect sales drop
‚úî Compare performance over time

Example:
If graph shows sudden decline in March,
company investigates reasons.

üîπ Additional Customization (Optional)

We can improve appearance:

python
plt.plot(months, sales, marker='o', linestyle='--', color='blue')

Adds:

  • Markers

  • Line style

  • Color

üîπ Summary

FunctionPurpose
plt.plot()Create line plot
plt.xlabel()Label X-axis
plt.ylabel()Label Y-axis
plt.title()Add title
plt.show()Display graph

‚úÖ Conclusion

A line plot in Matplotlib is created using the plt.plot() function and can be enhanced with labels and titles for clarity. Line plots are widely used in business analytics to visualize trends over time, helping managers make informed decisions based on data patterns.

Status: Unit 6 | Topic: Data Visualization using Matplotlib | 5 Marks | Q 73/10

Question 73:

Explain how to create a bar chart in Matplotlib and its use in business comparison analysis.
(Source: )

‚úÖ Introduction

A bar chart is used to compare values across different categories.

Think of it like:

üëâ Comparing sales of different products
üëâ Comparing performance of departments
üëâ Comparing revenue of branches

Each category is represented by a rectangular bar.

üîπ Basic Syntax

python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

plt.bar(categories, values)
plt.show()

üîπ Example: Product Sales Comparison

python
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

products = ["Laptop", "Mobile", "Tablet"]
sales = [50000, 30000, 20000]

plt.bar(products, sales)

plt.xlabel("Products")
plt.ylabel("Sales")
plt.title("Product Sales Comparison")

plt.show()

üîπ Explanation

1Ô∏è‚É£ plt.bar()

Creates vertical bars.

2Ô∏è‚É£ Categories (X-axis)

Products like Laptop, Mobile, Tablet.

3Ô∏è‚É£ Values (Y-axis)

Corresponding sales values.

4Ô∏è‚É£ Labels & Title

Make chart understandable.

üîπ Horizontal Bar Chart

python
plt.barh(products, sales)
plt.show()

Useful when category names are long.

üîπ Business Use Cases

Bar charts are useful for:

‚úî Comparing product sales
‚úî Comparing employee performance
‚úî Comparing branch revenue
‚úî Comparing yearly profit

üîπ Business Example

Suppose company wants to compare:

  • Sales of 3 branches

  • Performance of 5 employees

  • Market share of 4 products

Bar chart clearly shows:

‚úî Highest performer
‚úî Lowest performer
‚úî Difference between categories

üîπ Why Bar Charts Are Effective

‚úî Easy to compare values
‚úî Clear visual difference
‚úî Good for presentations
‚úî Suitable for categorical data

üîπ Summary Table

FunctionPurpose
plt.bar()Vertical bar chart
plt.barh()Horizontal bar chart
plt.xlabel()Label X-axis
plt.ylabel()Label Y-axis
plt.title()Add title

‚úÖ Conclusion

A bar chart in Matplotlib is created using the plt.bar() function and is widely used for comparing categorical data. It helps businesses visually analyze differences between products, departments, or regions, making comparison-based decision-making easier and more effective.
